title: The Civil War Begins
subtitle: Bull Run to Antietam (1861-1862)

sections.title: First Bull Run—The Illusion Shatters
sections.summary: I'm Thomas, seventeen years old, and I enlisted in the Union Army in May 1861. The war fever in my hometown of Cleveland was intense. After Fort Sumter fell, President Lincoln called for 75,000 volunteers.

sections.title: Building an Army
sections.summary: After Bull Run, the Union Army transformed. General George McClellan took command. He was young, energetic, and organized.

sections.title: The Peninsula Campaign—Frustration
sections.summary: Spring 1862. McClellan's Peninsula Campaign began with promise and ended in frustration. We landed over 100,000 troops on the peninsula between the York and James Rivers, planning to march up to Richmond, just 70 miles away.

sections.title: Second Bull Run—Defeat Again
sections.summary: After McClellan's Peninsula Campaign failed, Lincoln tried a new approach. He brought General John Pope from the West to command a new Army of Virginia. Pope was confident, even arrogant.

sections.title: Antietam—The Bloodiest Day
sections.summary: September 17, 1862. Antietam. The bloodiest single day in American history.
